qas.question: What does the third type of solution to the problem of the direction of time argue?

answers.text: the laws are not time-reversal symmetric

qas.question: What is are kind of nuclear force is not time-reversibile?
Time asymmetric phenomena in quantum mechanics are to few to account what kind of time-asymmetry?
What does the thirs solution argue is time-reversal symmetric?

plausible_answers.text: relating to the weak nuclear force,

qas.question: What processes in quantum mechanics are reversable?
What asymmetric phenomena are common in quantum mechanics?

context: A third type of solution to the problem of <b3_0>the direction of time<b3_0/>, although much less represented, argues that <a0_0>the laws are not time-reversal symmetric<a0_0/>. For example, certain processes in quantum mechanics, <b4_0>relating to the <a1_0>weak nuclear force<a1_0/>,<b4_0/> are not time-reversible, keeping in mind that when dealing with quantum mechanics time-reversibility comprises a more complex definition. But this type of solution is insufficient because 1) the <b5_0>time-asymmetric phenomena<b5_0/> in quantum mechanics are too few to account for the uniformity of <a2_0>macroscopic<a2_0/> time-asymmetry and 2) it relies on the assumption that quantum mechanics is the final or correct description of physical processes.[citation needed]
